docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Bernice Olson heard in 1992 that a nationwide study was under way to determine whether the drug tamoxifen could prevent breast cancer in high-risk women, she volunteered right away. One of her sisters, who is now healthy, had had the disease in 1980, at the age of 43. That, combined with Mrs. Olson's own age, 51, defined her as high risk. Last week she and others in the study received a letter marked ''urgent,'' notifying her that the experiment had been halted a year early, because tamoxifen had shown such a powerful protective effect -- 45 percent fewer cases of breast cancer in the women taking it -- that the scientists felt ethically bound to offer the drug to all the women in the study, some of whom had been assigned to a group that were taking placebos.

headline.main: Breast Cancer Drug Dilemma: Who Should Take It, and When?

docs.abstract: Tamoxifen has been shown to have strong protective effect on women at high risk for breast cancer, but researchers have not yet analyzed enough data to develop recommendations on which women should take it and when; Dr Leslie Ford of National Cancer Institute says it hopes to have information available within 'weeks or months' that women and doctors could use to assess an individual woman's risk of developing breast cancer and of suffering serious side effects from tamoxifen, which include small increases in risk of blood clots, uterine cancer and depression; it will not be able to offer simple set of guidelines that would apply to everyone; photo; graph shows increase of breast cancer risk with age (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE'S an illegal drug making huge inroads in New Jersey, trapping not only the most hardened of inner-city users, but also fresh-faced suburban youngsters who weren't even born when the nation started its war on drugs. The drug is heroin: same old powerfully addictive opiate derivative, brand new pattern.
docs.abstract: Article on heroin addiction problem that has spread among some young people in some New Jersey suburbs; easy availability in nearby cities and purity of Colombian heroin blamed; state has about 10,000 heroin addicts in treatment, but absence of solid data means that few newspaper headlines are fueling inordinate public anxiety; Michael Massing, author of new book on nation's drug policy, says most of heroin is still consumed by people in inner city who add it to their cocaine habit; Dr Lance Gooberman offers unusual rapid detoxification under general anesthesia, during which he implants pellet with month-long dose of heroin-blocking drug; reports majority of his patients, including his own niece, Nicole Oilson, stay clean for months; photos (S)
